redFlags.title: @:home.redFlags

intro.p1: Human trafficking is modern-day slavery. Traffickers use force, fraud and coercion to control their victims. Any minor engaged in commercial sex is a victim of human trafficking. While the initial purchase of victims may occur online, the real-time sale of victims can happen in many locations, including truck stops, restaurants, rest areas, hotels/motels, strip clubs, private homes, etc.
intro.p2: Truckers are the eyes and the ears of our nation’s highways. If you see a minor working any of those areas or suspect that the person selling sex is under someone else’s control in order to make a quota, call the National Hotline and report your tip.
intro.warning: Warning: Please do not approach traffickers.
intro.p3: Allow law enforcement to deal with traffickers and recover victims. Approaching traffickers is not only dangerous for you and their victims but could lead to problems in the eventual prosecution of traffickers.

questions.title: Questions
questions.subtitle: If you suspect someone is a victim of human trafficking, here are some questions to ask him/her.
questions.1: Do you keep your own money? If not, who does?
questions.2: Do your parents/siblings/relatives know where you are? If not, why not?
questions.3: When was the last time you saw your family?
questions.4: Are you physically or sexually abused?
questions.5: Are you or your family threatened?
questions.6: What is the nature of the threats?

flags.subtitle: Trafficking Red Flags to look for:
flags.1: Lack of knowledge of their whereabouts; not in control of ID/passport
flags.2: Restricted or controlled communication-not allowed to speak for self
flags.3: CB chatter about “commercial company” or flashing lights signaling “buyer” location
flags.4: Acknowledgement of a pimp and making a quota
flags.5: Signs of branding or tattooing of trafficker’s name (often on the neck)
flags.6: A van or RV that seems out of place out by trucks; a vehicle dropping someone off at a truck and picking them up 15–20 minutes later

redFlags.post1: If you haven't seen the TAT Training DVD you can go to our
redFlags.post1Link: education portal to complete your TAT Training
redFlags.post2: If you have seen the TAT Training DVD and reviewed this content, please register as TAT Trained

caseStudy.title: Case Study
caseStudy.a:
On Jan. 9, 2018, professional driver Arian Taylor pulled into a Compton, California business to make a delivery at 3:30 a.m. Shortly thereafter, he received a knock on his cab door, only to find a 19-year-old young woman standing outside his truck. As he spoke with her, he learned that her friend’s older boyfriend was trying to force her into prostitution. After she had refused and argued with him, he dumped her in the parking lot and sped off.

She was cold, exhausted, had no money, no identification, was carrying everything she owned in her arms and was desperate to get back home to Las Vegas. At that point, Arian told her, “I will find a way to get you home.” After getting her warm and giving her water to drink, Arian looked at one of the two TAT stickers prominently displayed on his window (which the victim had been eye-level with when she knocked on his door) and called the National Human Trafficking Hotline.

They worked with him to secure the woman shelter for the night, a pre-paid cab ride to get her to that shelter and a chaperoned train ride back to Las Vegas the next day, where she was reunited with a family member. Arian took care of the young women until she was placed in the cab, and even gave her his personal cell phone number in case she needed anything else.
caseStudy.b: Laura Sorensen and Aldair Hodza, who made national news when arrested on Jan. 6, 2015 in VA at a truck stop. According to the incident report, officers were called to the scene at 3:20 p.m. and were allowed inside the RV by the occupants, who said they were in the area on vacation and to visit Sorenson’s daughter. The officers, however, observed that the alleged victim appeared frightened and exhibited signs of malnutrition. A State Police trooper took the young woman outside, where she began to weep and beg the trooper not to let her return to the RV. She told the trooper she was being held against her will and had been abused sexually and physically by the suspects. She also said the suspects threatened to kill or injure her family. She said she had infections all over her body and couldn’t remember the last time she had anything to eat or drink, adding that several days had passed.
caseStudy.c: William had parked in a truck stop for the evening when an underage girl knocked on his truck door and solicited him for sex. After William told the girl he was not interested, he observed her knocking on the doors of several other trucks before getting into one. During this time, William also saw an adult man walking around the lot and noticed that he appeared to be watching the girl closely.
caseStudy.d: Branding is used to indicate ownership by a trafficker. These are some examples of what branding can look like, and where it can be on the body.

report.title: @:home.reportActivity
report.intro:
Immediately: If you’re watching a crime in progress, call 911 and then call the hotline. If you’re at a truck stop/travel plaza or any other place of business, please notify the manager-on-duty of the suspicious activity; she/he needs to be aware of what is taking place on their property and assist in ending it.

Anti-Trafficking Hotline Advocates are available 24/7 to take reports of potential human trafficking. All reports are confidential and you may remain anonymous. Interpreters are available. The information you provide will be reviewed by the National Hotline and forwarded to specialized law enforcement and/or service providers where appropriate.
report.emailBtnHint: A phone call is strongly preferred

whatToReport.title: @:report.whatToReportBtn
whatToReport.intro: For law enforcement to open an investigation on your tip, they need “actionable information.” This would include:
whatToReport.carsText: Are there any vehicles involved in the suspects activity? Record the make, model, color, license plate number, etc.
whatToReport.peopleText: Who is involved in the activity? Make note of height, weight, hair color, eye color, age, etc. Take photos if possible to show to the authorities when they arrive.
whatToReport.dateTimeText: When did the suspicious activity happen? What day and what time?
whatToReport.locationText: Where did the suspicious activity take place? Do you have an address? Be as specific as you can.

resources.title: @:nav.resources
resources.intro: Use the resources below to learn more about trafficking and how you can get involved.

laws.title: @:resources.btns.humanTraffickingLaws
laws.intro2: Human trafficking is the recruitment, transportation, transfer, harboring or obtaining of persons through force, fraud and coercion for the purpose of exploitation.

bullets.1: All 50 states and D.C. have a law criminalizing sex trafficking
bullets.2: 31 states have a buyer applicable trafficking law that prohibits a mistake of age defense in prosecutions for buying a commercial sex act with any minor under 18
bullets.3: Some states punish sex purchasers the same as traffickers, generally with felony level crimes
bullets.4: Washington identifies anyone who purchases a sexually explicit act as a human trafficker guilty of a class-A felony
bullets.5: There is a lifetime ban on a CDL for any individual who uses their CMV in committing a felony involving a severe form of human trafficking

laws.linkText: Learn more about the human trafficking laws in the US.

about.title: About Truckers Against Trafficking
about.intro: We exist to educate, equip, empower, and mobilize members of the trucking and busing industries to combat domestic sex trafficking as a regular part of their jobs.

goals.1: Saturate trucking and related industries with TAT materials
goals.2: Partner with law enforcement and government agencies to facilitate the investigation of human trafficking
goals.3: Marshal the resources of our partners to combat this crime

video1.title: TAT Training Video
video1.description: Hear from truckers who have seen human trafficking on their routes, the FBI, a trafficking victim rescued through the call of a trucker, and information on concrete ways members of the trucking/travel plaza industry can fight this crime in the course of their daily work.

video2.title: Be a Changemaker!
video2.description: Hear the story of Kevin Kimmel the 2015 Harriet Tubman Award winner and change maker of the highway.

video3.title: TAT Law Enforcement Training
video3.description:
Truckers Against Trafficking presents this training on human trafficking and information on how law enforcement can investigate and prosecute this crime.

Thank you to our sponsors Help Inc. and Vigilant Solutions and our partners at iEmpathize for helping to make this training video possible.

video4.title: TAT Wallet Card Webinar
video4.description: A brief training on the elements of the TAT wallet card.
